<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 214, 907, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 277, 232, 293]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 277, 907, 293]]<|/det|>
9709/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 303, 343, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[730, 303, 907, 320]]<|/det|>
February/March 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 330, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 450, 763, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 466, 809, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 482, 566, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 513, 364, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 528, 870, 558]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 558, 485, 573]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 573, 885, 603]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 603, 860, 634]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 666, 215, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 682, 388, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 697, 732, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Harry has a five-sided spinner with sectors coloured blue, green, red, yellow and black. Harry thinks the spinner may be biased. He plans to carry out a hypothesis test with the following hypotheses.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[348, 112, 650, 139]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{H}_0\colon \mathrm{P}(\mathrm{the~spinner~lands~on~blue}) = \frac{1}{5}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[348, 139, 650, 163]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{H}_1\colon \mathrm{P}(\mathrm{the~spinner~lands~on~blue})\neq \frac{1}{5}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 625, 186]]<|/det|>
Harry spins the spinner 300 times. It lands on blue on 45 spins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 770, 217]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximation to carry out Harry's test at the \(5\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 198, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 500 households in a certain town was chosen. Using this sample, a confidence interval for the proportion, \(p\), of all households in that town that owned two or more cars was found to be \(0.355 < p < 0.445\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the confidence level of this confidence interval. Give your answer correct to the nearest integer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 150, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
In the past the time, in minutes, taken by students to complete a certain challenge had mean 25.5 and standard deviation 5.2. A new challenge is devised and it is expected that students will take, on average, less than 25.5 minutes to complete this challenge. A random sample of 40 students is chosen and their mean time for the new challenge is found to be 23.7 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
Assuming that the standard deviation of the time for the new challenge is 5.2 minutes, test at the \(1\%\) significance level whether the population mean time for the new challenge is less than 25.5 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 183, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the difference between the heights of two randomly chosen buildings in the city is less than 1 m.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
In a game a ball is rolled down a slope and along a track until it stops. The distance, in metres, travelled by the ball is modelled by the random variable \(X\) with probability density function

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 114, 655, 149]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} - k(x - 1)(x - 3) & 1\leqslant x\leqslant 3,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 157, 293, 175]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 189, 146, 207]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 188, 507, 207]]<|/det|>
Without calculation, explain why \(\mathrm{E}(X) = 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 189, 920, 207]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 432, 143, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 432, 292, 451]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = \frac{3}{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 432, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Two ponds, \(A\) and \(B\), each contain a large number of fish. It is known that \(2.4\%\) of fish in pond \(A\) are carp and \(1.8\%\) of fish in pond \(B\) are carp. Random samples of 50 fish from pond \(A\) and 60 fish from pond \(B\) are selected.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 134, 757, 154]]<|/det|>
Use appropriate Poisson approximations to find the following probabilities.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 165, 195, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 164, 845, 183]]<|/det|>
The samples contain at least 2 carp from pond \(A\) and at least 2 carp from pond \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The random variables \(X\) and \(Y\) have the distributions \(\mathrm{Po}(\lambda)\) and \(\mathrm{Po}(\mu)\) respectively. It is given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 109, 432, 131]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{P}(X = 0) = [\mathrm{P}(Y = 0)]^2,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 133, 692, 154]]<|/det|>
* \(\mathrm{P}(X = 2) = k[\mathrm{P}(Y = 1)]^2\), where \(k\) is a non-zero constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 165, 316, 184]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
